fields.label: Abstract
fields.comment: Any entity that does not occupy a position in space and  time. See SUMO for a detailed explanation.

fields.label: AcousticProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties concerning the acoustic nature of speech sounds.

fields.label: Adjectival
fields.comment: An adjectival, or 'adjective', is a part of speech whose members modify nouns. An adjectival specifies the attributes of a noun referent. Note: this is one case among many. Adjectivals are a class of

fields.label: AdjectivePhrase
fields.comment: AdjectivePhrase is the class of phrases that have adjectives as heads.

fields.label: AdjunctSubordinate
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: Adposition
fields.comment: An adposition is a part of speech whose members are of a closed set and occur before or after a complement composed of a noun phrase, noun, pronoun, or clause that functions as a noun phrase and forms

fields.label: Adverbial
fields.comment: An adverbial, or 'adverb', narrowly defined, is a part of speech whose members modify verbs for such categories as time, manner, place, or direction. An adverbal, broadly defined, is a part of speech

fields.label: Adverbializer
fields.comment: An adverbializer is a subordinating connective that links a subordinate clause  to a main clause, and indicates that the subordinate clause has an adverbial or interpropositional relation  to the main

fields.label: AirstreamProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: AnteriorProperty
fields.comment: Properties characterized by focusing on the upper passive articulator on the roof of the mouth [Ladefoged 1997, 597].

fields.label: ApicalityProperty
fields.comment: Properties characterized by focusing on the action of the lower, active articulator, ie which part of the tounge is used in articulation [Ladefoged 1997, 597].

fields.label: Article
fields.comment: An article is a member of a small class of determiners that identify a noun's definite or indefinite reference, and new or given status [Crystal 1997,26].

fields.label: ArticulatoryProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties concerning how sounds are produced in the mouth.

fields.label: AspectProperty
fields.comment: The term 'aspect'; designates the perspective taken on the internal temporal organisation of the event, and different values of the Aspect Feature distinguish different ways of viewing the internal te

fields.label: AttestedVariety
fields.comment: AttestedVariety is the class of human language varieties that have been observed by a linguist, and for which there is at least some record and/or data. Examples of attested varieties include all of t

fields.label: BacknessProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties describing sounds based on the relative horizontal position of the tongue. Note, Ladefoged refers to this property as Back.

fields.label: BinaryPredicator
fields.comment: BinaryPredicator is the class of syntactic words that take two required arguments.

fields.label: BoundCompound
fields.comment: BoundCompound is the class of compounds that cannot exist on their own.

fields.label: BoundRoot
fields.comment: BoundRoot is the class of bound units whose members are common to a set of derived or  inflected units, if any, when all  other bound units are removed  [Crystal 1985,268; Hartmann and Stork 1972,199;

fields.label: BoundUnit
fields.comment: BoundUnit is the class of morphological units that cannot exist on their own. That is, they must be attached to at least one other grammatical constituent.

fields.label: BuccalProperty
fields.comment: A subclass of place Properties roughly referring to positions inside the mouth [Ladefoged 1997, 606].

fields.label: CardinalNumeral
fields.comment: A cardinal numeral is a numeral of the class whose members are considered basic in form, are used in counting, and are used in expressing how many objects are referred to [Crystal 1997,52].

fields.label: CaseProperty
fields.comment: CaseProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of a noun's relationship (syntactic or semantic) to some other element in the sentence, such as a verb, noun, pronoun, or

fields.label: CategoryChanger
fields.comment: CategoryChanger is a cover class for all derivational units that change the syntactic category of the root to which they are attached.

fields.label: Character
fields.comment: A Character is the computational equivalent of a grapheme. For instance, a Unicode code point represents an instance of a character, such as LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A.

fields.label: Classifier
fields.comment: Classifier is a kind of operator used to indicate the syntactic class of some word.

fields.label: Clause
fields.comment: Clause is the class of constructions that form minimal sentential units. They must  include a predicate, all arguments of the predicate, and all modifiers of the predicate and the arguments.

fields.label: Clitic
fields.comment: Clitic is the class of units which members exhibit syntactic characteristics of a lexical unit, but show evidence of being morphologically bound to another lexical unit, the host, by being unstressed

fields.label: CommonNoun
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: ComparativeAdjective
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: ComplementSubordinate
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: Complementizer
fields.comment: A complementizer is a connective which marks a complement clause [Crystal 1997,75].

fields.label: ComplexBoundStem
fields.comment: ComplexBoundStem is the class of  stems that are made up of at least two grammatical units and that cannot exist without the addition of other units.

fields.label: ComplexBoundUnit
fields.comment: ComplexBoundUnit is the class of complex units that cannot exist on their own.

fields.label: ComplexFreeStem
fields.comment: ComplexFreeStem is the class of  stems that are made up of at least two grammatical units and that can exist without the addition of other units.

fields.label: ComplexFreeUnit
fields.comment: ComplexFreeUnit is the class of complex units that exist on their own.

fields.label: ComplexSpecification
fields.comment: A ComplexSpecification is a kind of FeatureSpecification whose value must be a FeatureStructure. This class gives a feature system its recursive properites [Maxwell, Simons, and Hayashi 2000].

fields.label: ComplexUnit
fields.comment: ComplexUnit is the class of morphologically complex grammatical units that consist of two or more other morphological units as constituents.

fields.label: Compound
fields.comment: Compound is the class of complex units whose members are composed of at least two roots.

fields.label: Conjunction
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: Connective
fields.comment: Also known as a conjunction, a Connective is a class of parts of speech whose members syntactically link words or larger  constituents, and expresses a semantic relationship between them. A conjunctio

fields.label: ContextOfUseTaxon
fields.comment: ContextOfUseTaxon is the class of taxons whose instances  classify language varieties according to how they are primarly used.

fields.label: CoordinatingConnective
fields.comment: A coordinating connective is a connective that links constituents without syntactically subordinating one to the other [Crystal 1997,93].

fields.label: Copulative
fields.comment: A type of Verb, e.g., 'seem' and 'appear'.

fields.label: CoronalProperty
fields.comment: Properties of sounds produced with passive articulators lying on the coronal axis.

fields.label: CorrelativeConnective
fields.comment: A correlative connective is either of a pair of  coordinating conjunctions (connectives) used in ordered fashion. Typically, one is used immediately before each member of a pair of constituents [Cryst

fields.label: DefiniteArticle
fields.comment: An definite article is a part of speech whose members refer to a specific, identifiable entity (or class of entities) [Crystal 1997,107].

fields.label: Demonstrative
fields.comment: A demonstrative is a determiner that is used deictically to indicate a referent's spatial, temporal, or discourse location. A demonstrative functions as a modifier of a noun, or a pronoun [Crystal 199

fields.label: DerivationalUnit
fields.comment: DerivationalUnit is the class of functional units whose members function to derive a new lexical unit from an existing one, by systematically changing the meaning and possibly altering the part of spe

fields.label: DerivedUnit
fields.comment: DerivedUnit is the class of free morphological units consiting of a root or stem plus at least one derivational unit.

fields.label: DescribedVariety
fields.comment: DescribedVariety is the class of  distinct human languages or language varieties as recognized by a linguist or a particular linguistic community, but not necessarily recognized by the ISO 639-3 stand

fields.label: Determiner
fields.comment: A Determiner is a part of speech whose members belong to a class of noun modifiers and express the reference, including  quantity, of a noun [Crystal 1997,112].

fields.label: Diacritic
fields.comment: A Diacritic is a small mark added to a glyph (usually above or below) used to indicate stress, tone, or some kind of change in the quality of the segment represented by the glyph. Diacritics are used

fields.label: Dialect
fields.comment: A Dialect is a GeneticTaxon, such that: (a) there is at least one other dialect to which the particular instance of dialect is compared, (b) the two dialects are mutually intelligible, and (c) there i

fields.label: Digraph
fields.comment: A Digraph is a sequence of glyphs used in some writing systems to represent a single phoneme. For instance, 'ng' is used to represent the velar nasal in several Germanic languages.

fields.label: DiscourseUnit
fields.comment: The most general unit at the level of discourse. [This domain needs work.]

fields.label: Disjunction
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: DistributiveNumeral
fields.comment: A distributive numeral is a numeral which expresses a group of the number specified.

fields.label: DitransitiveVerb
fields.comment: A ditransitive verb is a verb that takes two objects [Crystal 1997,397].

fields.label: DorsalProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties associated with sounds made with the body of the tongue [Ladefoged 1997, 601]. Almost all vowels can be described using subclasses of this property.

fields.label: Enclitic
fields.comment: An enclitic is a clitic that is phonologically joined at the end of a preceding lexical unit to form a single phonological unit [Crystal 1980,64; Pei and Gaynor 1954,65].

fields.label: EndangermentTaxon
fields.comment: EndangermentTaxon is a class of taxons based on the robustness of its members. Endangerment is based on a number of criteria including the number of speakers, the average age of the native-speaker pop

fields.label: EvaluativeProperty
fields.comment: EvaluativeProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of judged value. These properties are associated with nominals that generally indicate that the referent is viewed f

fields.label: EvidentialityProperty
fields.comment: EvidentialFeature is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of the speaker's belief in what they say. It is closely related to mood, some of whose values indicate the strength o

fields.label: ExistentialMarker
fields.comment: An existential marker is a syntactic category whose members are found in distinct clause types and which mark a referent's existence [Crystal 1997,142].

fields.label: Expletive
fields.comment: An expletive (also known as a dummy word) is a part of speech whose members have no meaning, but complete a sentence to make it grammatical [Crystal 1997,127;].

fields.label: ExtinctVariety
fields.comment: ExtinctVariety is the class of human language varieties that no longer have native speakers, e.g., Frankish or Mozarabic.

fields.label: FeatureAgreementSystem
fields.comment: A type of FeatureDistributionSystem; in a given language, it is the system according to which feature values (of a particular feature) are determined for elements through agreement (i.e. where the for

fields.label: FeatureAssignmentSystem
fields.comment: In a given language, the system according to which feature values (of a particular feature) are assigned inherently to elements, based on the elements' inherent formal or semantic properties.

fields.label: FeatureConstraint
fields.comment: A FeatureConstraint is a LinguisticDataStructure which groups a part of speech value with a set of features. Within a FeatureSystem of some language, it indicates which Features may be associated with

fields.label: FeatureDistributionSystem
fields.comment: In a given language, the system according to which feature values (of a particular feature) are determined contextually for elements, through agreement or government.  FeatureDistributionSystem can ha

fields.label: FeatureGovernmentSystem
fields.comment: A type of FeatureDistributionSystem; in a given language, it is the system according to which feature values (of a particular feature) are determined for elements through government (i.e. where the fo

fields.label: FeatureSpecification
fields.comment: A FeatureSpecification is a data structure that groups together a linguistic feature with a value [Maxwell, Simons, and Hayashi 2000].

fields.label: FeatureStructure
fields.comment: A FeatureStructure is a set of one or more FeatureSpecifications. A FeatureStructure is a kind of information structure, a container or data structure, used to group together qualities or features of

fields.label: FeatureSystem
fields.comment: A 3-tuple: (1) a set of FeatureValues, (2) the particular FeatureAssignmentSystem according to which the values are assigned inherently to elements in the given language, and (3) the particular Featur

fields.label: ForceProperty
fields.comment: ForceProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of the speech act associated with a proposition. Among the traditionally defined values are Declarative, Imperative and I

fields.label: FormUnit
fields.comment: A FormUnit is any unit of linguistic form; the abstract form component of a linguistic sign. Subclasses include various phonology units such as Phoneme, Mora, PhonologicalWord, etc.

fields.label: FreeCompound
fields.comment: FreeCompound is the class of compounds that exist on their own.

fields.label: FreeRoot
fields.comment: FreeRoot is the class of roots  whose members can exist without the addition of another grammatical unit.

fields.label: FreeUnit
fields.comment: FreeUnit is the class of  morphological units that can exist on their own without being a constituent of  another morphological unit. Note that free units can also be syntactic units, namely syntactic

fields.label: FunctionalUnit
fields.comment: FunctionalUnit is the class of units that includes inflectional and derivational units. Functional units attach to roots and stems and can be used to form morphological paradigms in a grammatical desc

fields.label: Functor
fields.comment: Functor is the class of syntactic word whose members are neither relation- nor argument-like non-relational [Anderson 1997, 20]. Typical functors include adpositions, subordinators, and complementizer

fields.label: GenderProperty
fields.comment: GenderProperty is the class of properties that are assigned to nouns on the basis of their inherent properties by an AssignmentSystem and required by the syntax to appear on the target in an Agreement

fields.label: GeneticTaxon
fields.comment: GeneticTaxon is the class of all taxons whose members are based on genetic relatedness.

fields.label: GeographicTaxon
fields.comment: GeographicTaxon is the class of linguistic taxons whose instances are groupings based on where, in general, the language varieties are used, e.g., AustralianLanguage.

fields.label: Gerund
fields.comment: A part of speech derived from a verb and used as a noun, usually restricted to non-finite forms of the verb [Crystal 1997, 279].

fields.label: GlottalMovementProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: GlottalStrictureProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: GlottalTimingProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: Glyph
fields.comment: A Glyph is a symbol used in a writing system to represent some kind of linguistic unit, such as a single sound, a  phoneme or an entire word. Glyphs are concatenated in a writing system to form orthog

fields.label: GrammarUnit
fields.comment: A GrammarUnit is the structural component of the linguistic sign and includes notions such as morpheme, syntactic word, and construction. Grammar units are classified according to their mereology (par

fields.label: Grapheme
fields.comment: A Grapheme is the smallest meaningful contrastive unit in a writing system. A grapheme is an abstraction over a set of like glyphs, the actual images on the   page. That is, a particular grapheme is r

fields.label: Group
fields.comment: Group is the class of syntactic constructions intermediate between the level of word and phrase.

fields.label: HeightProperty
fields.comment: The class of features describing sounds based on the relative vertical position of the tongue. Note, Ladefoged refers to this feature as High.

fields.label: HumanLanguageVariety
fields.comment: Human language variety is the class of all discrete entities (as identified by a linguist) that are considered systems of signs in their own right, emerge gradually as a cultural artifact, and are use

fields.label: IndefiniteArticle
fields.comment: An article is a part of speech whose members are used to refer to an entity (or class of entities) which is not capable of specific identification [Crystal 1997, 193].

fields.label: IndefinitePronoun
fields.comment: An indefinite pronoun is a pronoun that belongs to a class whose members indicate  indefinite reference [Crystal 1997, 312].

fields.label: InflectedUnit
fields.comment: InflectedUnit is the class of morphological units consisting of a root or stem plus at least one inflectional unit.

fields.label: InflectionalUnit
fields.comment: InflectionalUnit is the class of functional units whose members designate such grammatical categories as tense, aspect, mood etc. The various forms of an InflectionalUnit plus the stem forms a grammat

fields.label: Interjection
fields.comment: An interjection is a part of speech, typically brief in form, such as one syllable or word, whose members are used most often as exclamations or parts of an exclamation. An interjection, typically exp

fields.label: InterlinearGlossedText
fields.comment: Interlinear glossed text (IGT) is a linguistic data structure meant to display morphosyntactic structure: morphemes, morpheme boundaries, morpheme types (clitics, prefixes, reduplicated forms), morpho

fields.label: InterrogativeOperator
fields.comment: Also referred to as a 'question particle', an interrogative operator is a category whose members signal a yes/no question [Payne 1997, 296].

fields.label: InterrogativeProform
fields.comment: An InterrogativeProform is a Proform that is used in questions to stand for the item questioned.

fields.label: IntransitiveVerb
fields.comment: An intransitive verb is a verb that cannot take a direct object, and describes a property, state, or situation involving only one participant [Crystal 1997,397; Payne 1997,171].

fields.label: Intransitivizer
fields.comment: A derivational unit that derives intransitive verbs from adjectives or other categories.

fields.label: Isolate
fields.comment: Isolate is the class of human language varieties such that there are no other varieties that are genetically related.

fields.label: LabialProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties associated with characteristics of labial articulations [Ladefoged 1997, 594].

fields.label: Language
fields.comment: The concept of a language is very difficult to define axiomatically. Here, we say that a language is a subclass of GeneticTaxon above the level of dialect. Language, in this sense, is often defined ac

fields.label: LanguageFamily
fields.comment: LanguageFamily is a relatively broad grouping of languages. In a given language family, all languages are genetically related.

fields.label: LanguageStock
fields.comment: LanguageStock is a wide grouping of languages based on genetic affiliation and at a higher level than a LanguageFamily. LanguageStock is defined according to the existence of language families.

fields.label: LanguageSubfamily
fields.comment: LanguageSubfamily is a grouping of languages defined more narrowly than a LanguageFamily. In a given Subfamily, all languages are genetically related and are instances of the same LanguageFamily. For

fields.label: LaryngealProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: LateralProperty
fields.comment: Characterizing sounds involving air released through side of the mouth.

fields.label: LexicalItem
fields.comment: The information structure used to encode all the information associated with an entry in a dictionary.

fields.label: LexicalizedConcept
fields.comment: LexicalizedConcept is the class of semantic units that are expressed as grammatical atoms in a language.

fields.label: Lexicon
fields.comment: A collection of LexicalItems.

fields.label: Ligature
fields.comment: A Ligature is a special type of glyph composed by two or more basic glyphs fused together as a single symbol.

fields.label: LinguisticDataStructure
fields.comment: A linguistic data structure is an abstract container for grouping together instances of linguistic data, usually to suit a particular theory or computational implementation. Examples include: feature

fields.label: LinguisticExpression
fields.comment: A LinguisticExpression is any physical form (sound, visual image or sequence thereof) used to represent a linguistic unit. A linguistic expression may be spoken, written, or signed. A linguistic expre

fields.label: LinguisticProperty
fields.comment: LinguisticProperty is the class  of properties that pertain to linguistic units. A unit's properties determine its behavior  in a grammatical system. Specific kinds of propertiess are relevant to cert

fields.label: LinguisticSign
fields.comment: A linguistic sign is an abstract structure whose instances participate in a linguistic system, or language. By definition, a linguistic sign must have a form component (whose elements are phonological

fields.label: LinguisticSystem
fields.comment: LinguisticSystem is the class of languages, broadly construed. It includes human, animal, and computer language. Furthermore, it includes natural and constructed varieties as well as written, signed,

fields.label: LinguisticTaxon
fields.comment: LinguisticTaxon is the class of  Taxons whose instances are used in the scientific classification language varieties. That is, instances of LinguisticTaxon have instances that are human language varie

fields.label: LinguisticUnit
fields.comment: The class of all kinds of units, defined according to the particular level of linguistic analysis.

fields.label: LivingVariety
fields.comment: LivingVariety is the class of human language varieties that are currently in use and have native speakers.

fields.label: MainClause
fields.comment: MainClause is the class of clauses that can stand on their own as a  full, independent sentence.  If a sentence contains any embedded clauses, the main clause is understood as the matrix plus the embe

fields.label: MannerProperty
fields.comment: A property of sounds that focuses on the active articulator and how the airstream is obstructed.

fields.label: Modal
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: ModalityProperty
fields.comment: ModalityProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of the status of the proposition itself, and not of the event to which the proposition refers, cf. AspectProperty [Pal

fields.label: MoodProperty
fields.comment: MoodProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of mood or force of a proposition. Among the traditionally defined properties are Declarative, Imperative and Interrogativ

fields.label: MorphologicalUnit
fields.comment: MorphologicalUnit subsumes all grammatical units below the level of the syntactic word. Only a morphological unit may be a constituent of another morphological unit.

fields.label: MorphosemanticProperty
fields.comment: Linguistic properties having a semantic component.

fields.label: MorphosyntacticProperty
fields.comment: MorphosyntacticFeature is the class of linguistic features that govern the grammatical behavior of morphosyntactic units. E.g., two morphosyntactic units can agree according to shared morphosyntactic

fields.label: MultiplicativeNumeral
fields.comment: A multiplicative numeral is a numeral that expresses how many fold or how many times [Pei and Gaynor 1954,149; Hartmann and Stork 1972,147].

fields.label: NasalityProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties  used to characterize the degree to which air  escapes through the nose.

fields.label: NearlyExtinctVariety
fields.comment: The class of languages that have relatively few native speakers. A nearly extinct variety is expected to become extrinct in a short time period, e.g., Jebero or Wichita.

fields.label: NegationOperator
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: Nominal
fields.comment: A nominal is a partOfSpeech whose members differ grammatically from a substantive but which functions as one [Crystal 1997, 260].

fields.label: NominalClassifier
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: NominalParticle
fields.comment: A nominal particle is a member of a closed class of particles that co-occur with nouns.

fields.label: Nominalizer
fields.comment: Nominalizer is the class of category changing units that change a verb or verb phrase to a corresponding nominal.

fields.label: Noun
fields.comment: A noun is a broad classification of parts of speech usually identifying time-stable concept [Crystal 1997,371].

fields.label: NounClassifier
fields.comment: A classifier is a partOfSpeech whose members express the classification of a noun [Crystal 1997,61; Payne 1997,107].

fields.label: NounPhrase
fields.comment: NounPhrase is the class of phrases that have nouns as heads. They can play the role of subject in a main clause.

fields.label: NumberProperty
fields.comment: NumberProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of quantity. It is often found on nouns, pronouns, and verbs and expresses count distinctions--such as 'one' or 'more th

fields.label: Numeral
fields.comment: A numeral is a partOfSpeech whose members function most typically as adjectives or pronouns and express a number, or relation to the number, such as one of the following: quantity, sequence, frequency

fields.label: NumeralClassifier
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: Object
fields.comment: Any entity that is stable throughout time and has other objects as parts. At any point in time, an object is wholly present. See SUMO for a detailed explanation.

fields.label: OrdinalNumeral
fields.comment: An ordinal numeral is a numeral belonging to a class whose members designate positions in a sequence [Crystal 1997,272].

fields.label: OrthographicPart
fields.comment: An OrthographicPart is a unit of an orthography that is not orthographically independent, that is, not necessarily able to stand alone as an orthographic word set off by whitespace. In the printed ins

fields.label: OrthographicPhrase
fields.comment: An OrthographicPhrase is a sequence of orthographic words.

fields.label: OrthographicSentence
fields.comment: An OrthographicSentence is a special type of orthographic phrase, usually representing a clause. In Western writing systems, an orthographic sentence is set off by white space on the left edge and som

fields.label: OrthographicWord
fields.comment: An OrthographicWord is a fundamental unit of an orthography, usually set off by white space and dependent on the rules of a writing system.

fields.label: Paragraph
fields.comment: A Paragraph is a self contained unit in written language composed of a sequence of orthographic sentences. Paragraphs are set off by vertical spacing, indentation or other conventions.

fields.label: PartOfSpeechProperty
fields.comment: PartOfSpeechProperty is the class of all kind of parts of speech.

fields.label: Participle
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: Particle
fields.comment: A particle is a part of speech whose members do not belong to one of the main classes of words, is invariable, and can have grammatical or semantic significance.

fields.label: PartitiveNumeral
fields.comment: A partitive numeral is a numeral that expresses a fraction [Pei and Gaynor 1954, 149; Hartmann and Stork 1972, 165].

fields.label: PersonProperty
fields.comment: PersonProperty is the class of properties  with a deictic dimension, interpreted relative to the speaker, encoding the participants in a speech situation. Usually a three-way contrast is found: firstP

fields.label: PersonalPronoun
fields.comment: A personal pronoun is a pronoun that expresses a distinction of person deixis.

fields.label: PhoneticProperty
fields.comment: The class of properties used to describe speech sounds. The properties given here are more or less taken directly from Ladefoged's later works, in particular, the taxonomies of [Ladefoged  1997].

fields.label: PhonologicalProperty
fields.comment: The class of linguistic properties that pertain to phonological units.

fields.label: Phrase
fields.comment: Phrase is the class of syntactic constructions that consist of one or more syntactic words, but lack the subject-predicate organization of a clause. Phrases get their grammatical characteristics accor

fields.label: PlaceProperty
fields.comment: The superclass of properties that specify the location of the articulators [Ladefoged 1997, 594].

fields.label: PlainAdjective
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: PolarityProperty
fields.comment: PolarityProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of negation. As a morphosyntactic property, generally only Negative is marked, i.e. associated with a linguistic expre

fields.label: PoliticalTaxon
fields.comment: PoliticalTaxon is the class of taxons whose instances are groupings based on political entities such as states or countries or larger politically defined entities, e.g., CameroonianLanguage.

fields.label: PossessivePronoun
fields.comment: A possessive pronoun is a pronoun that expresses ownership and relationships like ownership, such as kinship, and other forms of association [Crystal 1997,312].

fields.label: Postposition
fields.comment: A postposition is an adposition that occurs after its complement [Crystal 1997,300; Payne 1997,86].

fields.label: Predicator
fields.comment: Predicator is the class of syntactic words that are fundamentally relation inducing. That is, predicators license argument structure [Anderson 1997, 14]. Verbs are quintessential predicators, though o

fields.label: Prenoun
fields.comment: An element which may be compounded to the front of a noun to signal information such as size, color, etc. [Valentine 2001,  152-154].

fields.label: Preposition
fields.comment: A preposition is an adposition that occurs before its complement [Crystal 1997, 305; Payne 1997, 86].

fields.label: Preverb
fields.comment: An element which may be compounded to the front of a verb, to signal information such as tense, direction, etc. [Valentine 2001,  154-158].

fields.label: ProForm
fields.comment: A ProForm is a partOfSpeech whose members usually substitute for other constituents, including phrases, clauses, or sentences, and whose meaning is recoverable from the linguistic or extralinguistic c

fields.label: Proadjective
fields.comment: A Proadjective is a proForm that substitutes for an adjective or adjective phrase.

fields.label: Proadverb
fields.comment: A Proadverb is a Proform that substitutes for an adverb or other expression having an adverbial function.

fields.label: Process
fields.comment: Any entity that is relatively time unstable and has other processes as parts. See SUMO for a detailed explanation.

fields.label: Processive
fields.comment: A derivational unit that derives transitives from other transitives or intransitive verb (stems).

fields.label: Proclitic
fields.comment: A proclitic is a clitic that precedes the lexical unit to which it is phonologically joined [Crystal 1980,64; Hartmann and Stork 1972,185; Pei and Gaynor 1954,176].

fields.label: Pronominal
fields.comment: A Pronoun is a ProForm which functions like a noun and substitutes for a noun or  noun phrase [Crystal 1997,312].

fields.label: ProperNoun
fields.comment: ProperNoun, also referred to as proper names, is the class of nouns that are used to address particular persons or culturally significant personages or places. They refer to specific entities and are

fields.label: Proverb
fields.comment: no documentation yet

fields.label: PulmonicProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: Quantifier
fields.comment: A quantifier is a determiner that expresses a referent's definite or indefinite  number or amount. A quantifier functions as a modifier of a noun, or a pronoun [Crystal 1997, 317].

fields.label: RadicalProperty
fields.comment: The class of place  properties used to classifiy articulatory gestures made with the root of the tongue [Ladefoged 1997, 603].

fields.label: ReciprocalPronoun
fields.comment: A reciprocal pronoun is a pronoun that expresses a mutual feeling or action among the referents of a plural subject [Crystal 1997,323].

fields.label: ReflexivePronoun
fields.comment: A reflexive pronoun is a pronoun that has coreference with the subject.

fields.label: RelativePronoun
fields.comment: A relative pronoun is a pronoun that marks a relative clause, functions grammatically within the relative clause, and is coreferential to the word modified by the relative clause [Crystal 1997,329].

fields.label: Relativizer
fields.comment: A relativizer is a subordinating connective that links a relative clause to its head  noun. It is distinguishable from a relative pronoun in that it does not have a nominal function within the relativ

fields.label: Repetitive
fields.comment: A derivational unit that derives transitives from other transitive or intransitive stems adding the meaning of repitition to the resulting form.

fields.label: Root
fields.comment: Root is the class of morphologically simple units that are not further analyzable into meaningful elements, being morphologically simple. Roots  have a lexicalized meaning and designate the principle

fields.label: SecondLanguageOnlyVariety
fields.comment: A class of language varieties with no native speakers, i.e., only spoken by those that learned the variety after childhood.

fields.label: SemanticProperty
fields.comment: The class of linguistic properties that pertain to semantic units.

fields.label: SemanticUnit
fields.comment: A SemanticUnit is the class of semantics elements, or units of semantic structure (sometimes called a sememe). Semantic units serve as the meaning component of linguistic signs. A semantic unit is int

fields.label: SignedLanguage
fields.comment: SignedLanguage is the class of linguistic systems which instances are expressed using a system of (primarily manual) gestures.

fields.label: SignedLinguisticExpression
fields.comment: A SignedLinguisticExpression is the signed physical form of language as distinct from either written or spoken expressions. Signed expressions are the primary means in which sign languages are tranmit

fields.label: SimpleBoundStem
fields.comment: SimpleBoundStem is the class of unanalyzable stems that cannot exist without the addition of other units.

fields.label: SimpleBoundUnit
fields.comment: SimpleBoundUnit is the class of unanalyzable units that cannot exist without the addition of another morphological unit.

fields.label: SimpleFreeStem
fields.comment: SimpleFreeStem is the class of unanalyzable stems that can exist without the addition of other units.

fields.label: SimpleFreeUnit
fields.comment: SimpleFreeUnit is the class of  unanalyzable morphological units that can  exist alone, without the addition of another morphological unit.

fields.label: SimpleSpecification
fields.comment: A SimpleSpecification is a kind of FeatureSpecification whose value must be a simple linguistic attribute [Maxwell, Simons, and Hayashi 2000].

fields.label: SimpleUnit
fields.comment: SimpleUnit is the class of unanalyzable grammatical units, those with no other grammatical units as constituents.

fields.label: SizeProperty
fields.comment: SizeProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of relative size. Currently only Diminutive and Augmentative defined as possible properties. Typically, size is specified

fields.label: SpokenLanguage
fields.comment: SpokenLanguage is the class of linguistic systems whose instances are expressed in speech. For every spoken language, there exists a phonological system in which the language is expressed.

fields.label: SpokenLinguisticExpression
fields.comment: A SpokenLinguisticExpression is the physical sound form of language as distinct from either signed or spoken expressions. A spoken expression is the sound that is produced (and perceived) during a spe

fields.label: Stem
fields.comment: Stem is the class of  morphological units that are analyzable into a root and possibly one or more derivational units. Stems can occur alone and are the basis for adding inflectional units.

fields.label: StrictureProperty
fields.comment: Property of sounds produced by stricture of the vocal tract.

fields.label: StructuralDescription
fields.comment: This is a data structure commonly associated with morphosyntactic analysis. It is usually represented graphically as a tree.

fields.label: SubordinateClause
fields.comment: SubordinateClause is the class of clauses that cannot stand on their own as sentences.  A matrix clause combined with a subordinate clause form a main clause. In the sentence 'John thinks that Mary is

fields.label: SubordinatingConnective
fields.comment: A subordinating connective is a connective that links constructions by making one of them a constituent of another. The subordinating conjunction typically marks the incorporated constituent [Crystal

fields.label: Substantive
fields.comment: A substantive is a member of the syntactic class in which the names of physical, concrete, relatively unchanging experiences are most typically found whose members may act as subjects and  objects, an

fields.label: SuperlativeAdjective
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: SupraLaryngealProperty
fields.comment: Property of sounds characterized by focusing on the active articulator.

fields.label: SyntacticArgument
fields.comment: SyntacticArgument is the class of syntactic words that are fundamentally referable and  non-relational [Anderson 1997, 15]. Proper names are the quintessential arguments, though pronouns and nouns pos

fields.label: SyntacticConstruction
fields.comment: SyntacticConstruction is the class of grammar units that have syntactic structure, i.e., consisting of more than one syntactic word or construction in a syntactic configuration. [Crystal 1980, 85-86].

fields.label: SyntacticUnit
fields.comment: SyntacticUnit is the class of grammatical units whose members make up the constituents of syntactic constructions. They are the product of syntactic analysis. Syntactic units participate in syntactic

fields.label: SyntacticWord
fields.comment: SyntacticWord is the class of syntactic units occupying the lowest position in a syntactic construction.  They are the largest units resistant to insertion of new constituents within their boundaries;

fields.label: Taxon
fields.comment: Taxon is the class of scientific categories used to create a taxonomy and determined according to scientific principles in a given domain, e.g., Biology or Linguistics.

fields.label: TenseProperty
fields.comment: Following [Comrie 1985, vii], we take tense to be the grammaticalisation of location in time.  Tense Property is assigned to clauses on the basis of semantics: a tense value is selected for the clause

fields.label: Term
fields.comment: A specific string representing an entity within some scientific domain.

fields.label: Termset
fields.comment: A set of scientific terms used as part of an annotation system, usually the standard terms from a particular linguistic theory.

fields.label: TertiaryPredicator
fields.comment: TertiaryPredicator is the class of syntactic words that take three required arguments.

fields.label: Toneme
fields.comment: [No definition yet.]

fields.label: TransitiveVerb
fields.comment: A transitive verb is a verb that takes a direct object, and describes a relation between two participants [Crystal 1997,397; Payne 1997,171].

fields.label: Transitivizer
fields.comment: A derivational unit that derives transitive verbs from intransitive verb (stems).

fields.label: TrillProperty
fields.comment: A subclass of MannerFeature used to distinguish the various types of trills.

fields.label: UnaryPredicator
fields.comment: UnaryPredicator is the class of syntactic words that take only one required argument.

fields.label: UnattestedVariety
fields.comment: UnattestedVariety is the class of language varieties that are posited to exist or to have existed. Examples include reconstructed languages, such as Proto-Indo-European.

fields.label: VelaricProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: VerbPhrase
fields.comment: VerbPhrase is the class of phrases that have verbs as heads. They can play the role of predicate in a main clause.

fields.label: Verbal
fields.comment: A Verbal is a part of speech whose members typically signal events and actions; constitute, singly or in a phrase, a minimal  predicate in a  clause; govern the number and types of other constituents

fields.label: VerbalAdjective
fields.comment: suggested at E-MELD  (no documentation yet)

fields.label: VerbalParticle
fields.comment: A verbal particle is a member of a closed class of particles which co-occur with some verbs to form phrasal verbs. In some languages, verbal particles are identical to certain adpositions.

fields.label: Verbalizer
fields.comment: Verbalizer is the class of category changing units that change nouns into verbs.

fields.label: Versive
fields.comment: A derivational unit that derives intransitive stems from adjectives, with the meaning of becoming or taking on the quality of the adjective.

fields.label: VoiceProperty
fields.comment: VoiceProperty is the class of properties that concern the grammatical encoding of the relationship between the verb and the nominals in a subject-predicate configuration. It selects a grammatically pr

fields.label: VoicingProperty
fields.comment: [Need a definition.]

fields.label: WrittenLanguage
fields.comment: WrittenLanguage is the class of linguistic systems whose instance are expressed using a written, time-stable form. For every written language, there exists an orthographic system in which the language

fields.label: WrittenLinguisticExpression
fields.comment: A WrittenLinguisticExpression is the written physical form of language as distinct from either signed or spoken expressions. A written expression is the physical product of the writing process.

fields.label: ZeroPlacePredicator
fields.comment: ZeroPlacePredicator is the class of syntactic words that need not take any arguments, but act as predicators nevertheless.
